profileText: (Son of Benjamin Edwards), a Senator from Illinois; born at 'Mount Pleasant,' Montgomery County, Md., March 17, 1775; attended private schools; was graduated from Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., in 1792; studied law; moved to Bardstown, Ky., in 1795; member, State house of representatives 1796-1797; admitted to the bar in 1798 and commenced practice in Russellville, Ky.; judge of the general court of Kentucky 1803; judge of the circuit court 1804; judge of the court of appeals 1806; chief justice of the State 1808; Governor of the Territory of Illinois 1809-1818; upon the admission of Illinois as a State into the Union was elected as a Democratic Republican (and later as Adams-Clay Republican) to the United States Senate and served from December 3, 1818, to March 4, 1824, when he resigned; appointed Minister to Mexico in 1824, but while en route was recalled to testify before a select committee of the House of Representatives appointed to investigate charges made by him against William H. Crawford, Secretary of the Treasury; resumed the practice of law; interested in saw and grist mills and engaged in mercantile pursuits; Governor of Illinois 1826-1831; died in Belleville, Ill., on July 20, 1833; interment in Hutchinson Cemetery, Springfield, Ill.; reinterment in 1866 in Oak Ridge Cemetery, Springfield, Ill.

researchRecord.name: In Draper manuscripts, William Henry Harrison papers, 1811-1833 and William Clark papers, 1780-1804.
In William Wirt papers, 1786-1850, on 24 microfilm reels of originals in Maryland Historical Society; and John McLean papers, 1817-1861, on 18 microfilm reels of originals in Library of Congress.

1798-1833. Ca. 650 items. In part transcripts, chiefly correspondence relating to state and national politics. Includes material on presidential elections, Illinois gubernatorial elections, Indian affairs, the Burr conspiracy, the War of 1812 in and around Illinois Territory, and the Black Hawk War. Finding aid. Also ca. 40 miscellaneous items in various collections.
1799-1880. Ca. 180 items. Transcripts, partly of originals in the Chicago Historical Society. Correspondence relating to state and national politics.
